Honestly, I'd rather be completely fatherless, not saying that not having is better than having one, albeit a lousy one. However, I do believe that you can grow up completely fatherless and without any major male role model and still be successful. Take myself for example; I lived the first thirteen years of my life without a father, so to speak, and those were the essential times a kid needed to be around his/her father, I turned out great.

I'd rather be completely fatherless, but I do believe that you can grow up without a father. I grew up without a father and turned out great. Also, it's better for you to grow up without a father than with one who is a role model for you. For example, the man... someone who will try to legitimize his life as a man by having children, or by leaving an abusive wife.

Honestly, I'd rather be completely fatherless, not saying that not having is better than having one, albeit a lousy one. However, I do believe that you can grow up completely fatherless and without any major male role model and still be successful. Take myself for example; I lived the first thirteen years of my life without a father or any fatherly interaction, and those were the essential times a kid needed to be around his/her father, I turned out great.

Honestly, I'd rather be completely motherless, not saying that not having is better than having one, albeit a lousy one. However, I do believe that you can grow up completely motherless and without any major mother role model and still be successful. Take myself for example; I lived the first thirteen years of my life without a mother or any motherly interaction, and those were the essential times a kid needed to be around her/mother, I turned out great(Self-opinion). So yes, as opposed to having a lousy mother that would rub off on me and mold me into half a woman, I would much rather being motherless.

The adversarial judicial system can be somewhat efficient, and allow for fairly quick disposition of cases. Participants can learn from one another's arguments, which is helpful in taking on that jury function. There would be no lengthened delays due to appeals. It also allows for negotiations and counseling between the parties.

Rivalry can also push society to improve and compete, rather than relax and live in idle acceptance, and can ultimately encourage competitiveness and innovation. It also seems that parochialism (which typically exists in groups/communities) can be spread by adversarial reasoning and can be a detriment to a community.  What are the arguments against this system?  ### Response: The case presented in the paper suggests that this system has very damaging effects on the legal system.

It is more efficient than other systems of judicial review which enables you to have the truth come through quickly. It also allows for more evidence to be put to the defendent than a judge would be able to do. It also allows people to see and hear each other which is very important as the argument is worded and when it is spoken. It also makes the system available to more people to come into court and really debate their cases.

The adversarial judicial system helps to get at the truth because it presents each side of the case in writing; a viewer could not possibly know how each person in a case will feel. It also allows them the chance to present each side of the case in their own words which helps the viewer to form their own opinion about the case.

Nothing is an existential claim. "Nothing" asserts that what exists is not a thing in itself but the consequence of another thing. To state that no things exist, then, is saying that something exists.

Nothing exists. To utter that sentence - or even contemplate it - applies existence to something that is nothing. Yet to argue that nothing exists asserts - paradoxically - that in fact, no thing exists.

Everything exists except its very own lack of existence. And to state its existence means to state the absence of its own lack of existence. In other words, arguing that something exists implies that there is no such thing as not existing.

I have also had a lot of enjoyment talking to Steven (hope that's correct spelling), begging him to open a Peterborough location so I can enjoy the food more often. Yes, the difference between "pro-life" and "pro-choice" comes down to whether or not one believes a woman should have the option (choice) to terminate her pregnancy. By believing that this choice should be legal, one isn't advocating abortions (as in, they aren't pushing abortion on people or thinking that they're a good act). One can hold the position that abortions are morally bad, yet still believe the choice should be between a woman and her doctor. Likewise, one can be anti-choice yet still advocate for the death penalty, wars of aggression, etc.

I booked flights with Malaysia Airlines from Dublin to Hong Kong (via Heathrow and Kuala Lumpur) around 2 hours before the MH17 crash. Yesterday I received an email from the airline, offering a full refund up until 24th July, or offering to change bookings to a later date. I now have doubts about the safety record of the airline, even though it appears that there was nothing that could have been done to prevent the latest tragedy. The fate of flight MH370 remains unsolved, and declining consumer confidence appears to be reflected in the Malaysian stock market, which has experienced overall growth of 80% in the past five years while Malaysian Airlines stock price has fallen by the same figure. No, evolution isn't the beginning of life, and the big bang theory is a term for the bursting of molecules that began the creation of the universe. The big bang theory is a term used to describe the bursting of molecules that began the creation of the universe. The universe started out as a hot, dense space. Scientists know that because now nearby galaxies are moving further and further away, and the universe is expanding, so, in the past, the universe must have been hotter and more dense. Earth was the perfect candidate for life because it had the "goldilocks" conditions. Bacteria started to form from molecules, which formed into fish, then amphibians, then land animals, then monkeys, then humans.

You are responsible for the money under you,no matter how much your boss or the state said. But if you are fired, and you took money then an employee's employer can be sued for wrongful termination. If you can't prove you took the money, the employer can be sued also.

An employer should pay any wages,vacation,and other compensation (vacation pay,etc.) plus attorney's fees. The US labor department has established that you should get back any wages you received for termination. If the employer can't prove you took the money, you might be able to sue for wrongfull termination.

If an employer fires you,they have to pay any wages owed to you plus any other compensation (vacation pay,etc.) on the spot, and you can't sue your boss. On the other hand,a manager must be responsible for those under him,and the money. The boss has to prove you took the money,but you might be able to get your job back-talk to the state or Federal Dept. of Labor. You could possibly sue for Wrongful Termination if your boss can't prove you took the money.
